awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Securing Critical Infrastructure with Autonomously Secure Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
Embedded systems currently rely on local and often insecure state retention for process control and subsequent forensic analysis. As critical embedded control systems (e.g., smart grids, SCADA) generate increasing amounts of data and become ever more connected to other systems, secure retention and management of that data is required.  Attacks such as Stuxnet show that SCADA and other systems comprising critical infrastructure are vulnerable to the compromise of controllers and sensing devices, as well as falsification of data to circumvent anomaly detection mechanisms. 

This project develops techniques and architectures for securely storing and monitoring embedded system state in critical infrastructure. We are examining vulnerabilities relating to generating and storing data in critical embedded systems, which are often resource-constrained environments. We propose the design and deployment of 'autonomously secure storage devices' that act as resilient storage for embedded devices.  We are designing logging, audit, and management architectures for resiliently storing system data and provenance in the face of malicious and compromised devices. Additionally, we explore how this data may be disseminated to other systems and to environments such as the cloud and aim to protect data through privacy-preserving communication and querying interfaces, and attempt to make data-driven inferences about system operation to detect anomalous behavior. Through these active protections to generated data and metadata, we aim to provide a new baseline for producing and storing data generated within critical infrastructures.

por.por_cntn:
Embedded systems have become increasingly important to society as a whole. Powerful small computing platforms have allowed for advances in mobile devices, the programmable logic controllers (PLCs) used in cyber-physical systems, and increasingly in devices designed for the Internet of Things. Many challenges relate to the way in which data is stored, accessed, and communicated from these devices; failure to assure the security of this data can put entire cyber-physical systems at risk.

This project has made significant progress to assure the trustworthiness of data and the systems that generate it, as well as assuring privacy of users accessing this data. Through the funding this project received, we have built high-fidelity systems for collecting and securing data provenance, allowing us to track how information has been generated and modified throughout its lifetime. Our Hi-Fi and Linux Provenance Modules work has allowed for finer-grained trustworthy provenance collection than any previous work. This has been highly influential within the research community and it has been deployed as a key part of the MIT Lincoln Laboratory's Trustworthy Cloud Computing initiative. The idea of tracking data provenance in critical infrastructure also inspired work on designing access control mechanisms for cyber-physical systems. Our CPAC access control infrastructure for cyber-physical systems demonstrated that using the physics of a cyber-physical environment such as the smart grid could provide static access control rules, and doing dynamic analysis of flows through PLCs could allow fine-grained observation. Such a system could be used to prevent outages in the grid.

Beyond this work, the CAREER project supported initiatives in privacy-preserving computing using mobile devices and with the aid of trustworthy hardware to make these mechanisms more efficient, as well as the use of trustworthy computing to support safer computation and data storage. We developed the Dragchute system to create a time window during which locked data cannot be accessed by anyone. Dragchute uses a verifiable non-interactive, non-parallelizable, time-delay key escrow mechanism, but does not require retaining cryptographic material capable of providing early access to the data.

We also developed methods of securely retaining data to make it resistant to data breaches while allowing auditability. Our most recent initiatives involve examining machine learning for secure systems. We expose the ineffectiveness of underlying machine learning classification models used for system authentication by constructing a blind attack based around the query synthesis framework and utilizing Explainable AI (XAI) techniques. We launch an attack in under 130 queries on a state-of-the-art face authentication system, and under 100 queries on a host authentication system.

This work has also had significant training impact. Three students who were funded from this work have graduated and taken positions as assistant professors at institutions including the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Purdue University, and Point Loma Nazarene University.
